title: In The Home Of My Parents

slides.title: Birthplace: Braunau-on-the-Inn
content: Destiny's choice of Braunau as his birthplace was fortunate due to its location on the German-Austrian border.
Hitler views his life's mission as the reunion of German-Austria with the German Motherland, rejecting economic reasons.
Union is crucial even with economic disadvantages; shared blood necessitates unity within one REICH.
Colonial policies are secondary; REICH's priority is unifying all Germans to ensure their livelihood first.
slides.script: Welcome to the first chapter of Mein Kampf, 'In the Home of My Parents.' This slide highlights the significance of Braunau-on-the-Inn as Hitler's birthplace. It was chosen as a lucky turn of fate to be able to influence the merging of Austria and Germany. His goal was for a united REICH encompassing all Germans before considering any expansionist colonial policies.

slides.title: Johannes Palm: A Nationalist Inspiration
content: Braunau also symbolizes German nationalism; Johannes Palm, a bookseller, was executed there for loving Germany.
Palm's story highlights the risks of expressing German identity and resistance to foreign oppression during French rule.
Palm, like Leo Schlageter, was betrayed by a Government agent; both served as a source of inspiration.
These acts serve as a reminder of the dangers faced by German patriots and importance of resistance.
slides.script: This slide focuses on Johannes Palm, a nationalist figure. He was executed in Braunau for his love of Germany, symbolizing the struggle for German identity under foreign influence. His actions, even in death, served as a source of inspiration to those who followed.

slides.title: Family Life and Early Upbringing
content: Hitler's parents lived in Braunau; his father, a civil servant, was dutiful, and his mother dedicated herself to the family.
The family moved to Passau, Germany, then Linz, Austria, due to the nature of his father's civil service career.
Civil servant life was not an easy one; it required frequent moves which created some financial difficulties.
His father's life embodies diligence; he rose from poverty to become a civil servant, a position he valued highly.
slides.script: This slide looks at Hitler's family life. His parents are characterized as dutiful and loving. His father's career in the civil service led to frequent relocations. The slide also details his father's hard-won success as a civil servant, rising from poverty to a position he greatly cherished.

slides.title: Early Education and Aspirations
content: Hitler showed a disinterest in a civil service career; his inherent talent for speaking developed early.
The monastery choir in Lambach left an emotional imprint, making the Abbot seem like the highest aspiration.
He was captivated by stories of the Franco-German War of 1870-71, fostering an enthusiasm for military affairs.
This fueled initial questions about German identity; asking 'Are we not the same as the other Germans?'
slides.script: This slide examines Hitler's early education and aspirations. He preferred outdoor activities and showed a talent for public speaking. His experience in the monastery choir and exposure to military history ignited a passion for war, leading him to question his identity and the division among Germans.

slides.title: Conflict with Father's Plans
content: His father intended him to become a government official, deeming classical studies impractical.
The decision for the son to become a civil servant was seen as simple, definite, and clear.
At age eleven, Hitler openly opposed his father; determined to refuse a civil service career.
He found the idea of being tied to an office and filling out forms repulsive; fields and woods were where his disputes played out.
slides.script: This slide details Hitler's growing conflict with his father's plans for him to become a civil servant. He felt confined by the prospect of an office job and openly defied his father's expectations, highlighting a clash of wills and differing values.

slides.title: The Dream of Becoming an Artist
content: At age twelve, Hitler decided he would be a painter, an artist; his father vehemently opposed this ambition.
A stalemate ensued; the father refusing to yield, the son consolidating his resolve.
He sabotaged progress at the REALSCHULE, excelling only in geography and history.
This failure was aimed to compel his father to allow him to pursue his artistic dreams of painting.
slides.script: This slide focuses on his aspirations to become a painter. His father strongly opposed this, leading to further conflict and academic sabotage. Only excelling in subjects he thought would be beneficial for painting, such as geography and history. He was in the constant pursuit of doing what he loved.

slides.title: Emergence of Nationalism and Historical Awareness
content: His education fostered nationalism and a grasp of the true meaning of history, two significant facts in his life.
Austria was a multi-national State, and the Germans in the REICH could not fully grasp its implications.
Eastern Germans fought daily to preserve their language, schools, and German character.
He developed into an ardent 'German National,' distinguishing between dynastic patriotism and nationalism.
slides.script: This slide details the emergence of nationalism and a sense of history. His studies and environment led him to embrace German identity and understand the struggles of Germans within the multi-ethnic Austrian state. Leading to a split in the feelings of devotion to his people and his family.

slides.title: The Language Fight and Early Political Engagement
content: Language was central in Austria's ethnic struggle; it is where the youth had to learn where they belonged.
Schools were battlegrounds, children being rallied to uphold their German heritage.
He participated in South Mark German League and School League meetings; expressed loyalty to the movement.
Cornflowers, black-red-gold colors, HEIL greetings, and DEUTSCHLAND ÜBER ALLES were commonly used.
slides.script: Here we see the fight between the nationalities begin and the importance of keeping the children involved. The rallying cries and symbols of the German Youth were central to his own understanding of himself and his place within his people's hearts.

slides.title: Professor Poetsch and Historical Inspiration
content: Universal history was taught, little Austrian history; Austria's fate linked to Germany's development.
Historical relics in Vienna seemed more like magical charms than guarantees of unity.
Universal history teaching lacked focus; teachers missed the art of historical analysis.
His history professor, Dr. Leopold Poetsch, inspired enthusiasm and linked the past with the present, transforming history and making him a young rebel.
slides.script: Dr. Leopold Poetsch was a major influence in shaping Hitler's world view. Dr. Potsch was able to show how events in the past shaped the present, making a history a living, tangible force. It was this professor who caused Hitler to become a young rebel and question the world around him.

slides.title: Hatred for Habsburgs
content: He studied German history and became an enemy of the Habsburg State.
Habsburgs consistently betrayed German interests for personal gain; loyalty felt impossible.
Foreign races infiltrated Austria, even Vienna becoming less German; Czechs were favored by the Habsburg.
Archduke Franz Ferdinand, architect of a Slav Austria, fell victim to bullets he helped to cast.
slides.script: The focus turns to Hitler's growing hatred for the House of Habsburg. He saw them as betraying German interests and favoring Slavic populations, contributing to a deep sense of resentment towards the Austrian State. Leading to further radicalization of his own thinking.

slides.title: Convictions and Artistic Inclinations
content: He developed a strong love for his German-Austrian home and hatred for the Austrian State.
Dissolution of the Austrian Empire was seen as essential for Germany's defense.
Historical thinking and opera fueled aversion for his father's chosen career.
Architecture also captivated him, expanding his artistic interests beyond painting.
slides.script: This details the solidification of Hitler's convictions. He held strong feelings about the House of Habsburg, developing a love for German-Austria and a hatred for its State. Art and architecture also helped to push him away from the career his father wanted him to pursue.

slides.title: Father's Sudden Death and Career Shift
content: At thirteen, his father died suddenly, ending his earthly wanderings.
His mother felt duty-bound to continue his education, leading him toward the civil service.
His determination to avoid state service grew stronger, leading to indifference in middle school.
Illness intervened, with a doctor advising against office work due to lung issues; mother finally agreed to art academy.
slides.script: Hitler's father's sudden passing led to a pivotal moment. Despite his mother's initial intent to honor his father's wishes, illness intervened, paving the way for Hitler to pursue his artistic aspirations. At the time he was ill, he had a feeling of rejoice.

slides.title: Mother's Death and Departure for Vienna
content: Two years later, his mother's death ended his projects; poverty forced him to decide promptly.
With meagre resources, he packed and left for Vienna, mirroring his father's journey.
He was determined to become 'something,' but certainly not a civil servant; an artist.
He set out to forestall fate, driven by a sense of purpose and a rejection of the life planned for him.
slides.script: His mother's death brought harsh reality. With the family's resources depleted, he set off for Vienna with a strong resolve to pursue his artistic dreams, marking the end of his childhood and the beginning of a life-altering journey.
